article.title: Plants grown in Apollo lunar regolith present stress-associated transcriptomes that inform prospects for lunar exploration
funding: National Aeronautics and Space Administration grant NNX14AT24G
University of Florida Office of Research - Retuned IDC
National Aeronautics and Space Administration grant 80NSSC19K0752
article.abstract: The extent to which plants can enhance human life support on other worlds depends on the ability of plants to thrive in extraterrestrial environments using in-situ resources.

sections.introduction: The return of humans to the Moon during the NASA Artemis program has elevated scientific interest in the lunar environment and its impact on terrestrial biology.
sections.methods: All seeds used in the experiment were from the same batch of seeds from Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis) ecotype Columbia-0 (Col-0) (TAIR CS70000).
sections.results: Germination readily occurred on all samples between 48 and 60 hours after planting, and all lunar seedlings exhibited normal stems and cotyledons.
sections.discussion: The interaction between plants and lunar regolith will need to be further elucidated, and likely mitigated, to best enable efficient use of lunar regolith for life support within lunar stations.

article.insights_summary: Plants can germinate and grow in lunar regolith, but growth is challenging and plants exhibit stress-associated transcriptomes.
article.acknowledgments: We thank the members of the UF Space Plants Lab, particularly Jordan Callaham, Natasha Haveman, and Brandon Califar for their support.
